steps.description: Substrates are cleaned with acetone and methanol in an ultrasonic bath for 10-20 minutes each to remove dust particles.
The substrates are soaked in deionized (DI) water for 5-10 minutes in an ultrasonic bath, which transforms surface layers (either SrO or TiO2) into hydroxide complexes.

The hydroxide complexes on the surface are removed using buffered hydrofluoric acid (BHF), which is a solution of NH4F: HF = 7:1, with a pH of 4.5-5.5. This chemical etching process selectively removes strontium oxide (SrO) more strongly than TiO2, leading to the formation of soluble strontium hydroxide Sr(OH)2. The etching is performed for 30 seconds to a few minutes.

The chemically treated substrates are annealed at a high temperature of approximately 1000 °C in an O2 gas flow for 2-3 hours. This thermal treatment reconstructs the surface, producing an atomically flat layer with clear step-terrace structures of one unit-cell step height (~3.905 Å) and chemically homogeneous single termination. The surface is predominantly TiO2-terminated after this process.
Optionally, another deionized (DI) water rinsing may be applied after annealing to obtain fully single terminated atomically flat substrates.

equipment.name: Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry of Recoiled Ions (TOF-MSRI)

synthesis.notes: The treatment of as-received SrTiO3 (001) substrates is critical to achieve atomically flat and chemically homogeneous surfaces, which are indispensable for growing high-quality epitaxial thin films and heterostructures of transition metal oxides (TMOs) with atomically controlled interfaces. The 'Kawasaki method', involving wet acidic etching and subsequent thermal annealing, is widely adopted and results in a predominantly TiO2-terminated surface. This termination is crucial for achieving desired interface phenomena and properties in overlying films, particularly for applications in functional oxide electronics and two-dimensional electron gas systems.
